goals.question: What is the trend of the number of incidents reported during the LA riots?
goals.visualization: Line chart of the number of incidents reported over time
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the overall pattern of the incidents reported during the LA riots and identify any spikes or dips in the number of incidents.

goals.question: What is the distribution of the severity of the incidents reported during the LA riots?
goals.visualization: Histogram of the severity of incidents
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the distribution of the severity of incidents and identify any outliers or patterns in the data.

goals.question: What is the relationship between the severity of incidents and the number of people arrested?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot of severity of incidents vs number of people arrested
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there is any correlation between the severity of incidents and the number of people arrested, and if so, how strong the correlation is.

goals.question: What is the distribution of the age of the people arrested during the LA riots?
goals.visualization: Histogram of the age of people arrested
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the distribution of the age of people arrested and identify any patterns or outliers in the data.

goals.question: What is the trend of the number of incidents reported in different areas of LA during the riots?
goals.visualization: Stacked area chart of the number of incidents reported in different areas of LA over time
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the overall pattern of the incidents reported in different areas of LA during the riots and identify any areas that were particularly affected.

code:
```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['incident_date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['incident_date'], format='%m/%d/%Y %I:%M:%S %p', errors='coerce')
    data = data[pd.notna(data['incident_date'])]
    data = data.sort_values(by='incident_date')
    plt.plot(data['incident_date'], data['incident_count'], color='blue')
    plt.xlabel('Incident Date')
    plt.ylabel('Incident Count')
    plt.title('What is the trend of the number of incidents reported during the LA riots?')
    return plt

chart = plot(data)
```

```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['severity'] = pd.to_numeric(data['severity'], errors='coerce')
    data = data[pd.notna(data['severity'])]
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))
    sns.histplot(data=data, x='severity', kde=True, color='blue', ax=ax)
    ax.axvline(x=data['severity'].median(), color='red', linestyle='--', label=f'Median: {data["severity"].median():.2f}')
    ax.axvline(x=data['severity'].mean(), color='green', linestyle='--', label=f'Mean: {data["severity"].mean():.2f}')
    ax.set_xlabel('Severity')
    ax.set_ylabel('Frequency')
    ax.set_title('What is the distribution of the severity of the incidents reported during the LA riots?')
    ax.legend()
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    return plt

chart = plot(data)
```

```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['severity'] = pd.to_numeric(data['severity'], errors='coerce')
    data = data.dropna(subset=['severity', 'arrests'])
    plt.scatter(data['severity'], data['arrests'], alpha=0.5, color='red')
    plt.xlabel('Severity of Incidents')
    plt.ylabel('Number of People Arrested')
    plt.title('What is the relationship between the severity of incidents and the number of people arrested?')
    return plt

data = pd.read_csv('la-riots.csv')
chart = plot(data)
plt.show()
```

```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    sns.histplot(data=data, x='age', kde=True, color='blue')
    plt.axvline(data['age'].median(), color='red', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=1, label=f'Median Age: {data["age"].median():.2f}')
    plt.xlabel('Age')
    plt.ylabel('Count')
    plt.legend()
    return plt

data = pd.read_csv('la-riots.csv')
chart = plot(data)
```

```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('la-riots.csv')

# Convert date fields to date types
data['date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date'], format='%m/%d/%Y %H:%M:%S', errors='coerce')

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['date'])]

# Create a pivot table to aggregate the number of incidents by area and date
data_pivot = data.pivot_table(index='date', columns='area', values='count', aggfunc='sum')

# Create a stacked area chart
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))
data_pivot.plot.area(ax=ax, stacked=True)

# Set chart title
plt.title('What is the trend of the number of incidents reported in different areas of LA during the riots?', wrap=True)

# Set x-axis label
plt.xlabel('Date')

# Set y-axis label
plt.ylabel('Number of Incidents')

# Add legend
plt.legend(loc='upper left')

# Show plot
plt.show()
```

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('la-riots.csv')

# Convert date fields to date types
data['date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date'], format='%m/%d/%Y %H:%M:%S', errors='coerce')

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['date'])]

# Create a pivot table to aggregate the number of incidents by area and date
data_pivot = data.pivot_table(index='date', columns='area', values='count', aggfunc='sum')

# Create a stacked area chart
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))
data_pivot.plot.area(ax=ax, stacked=True)

# Set chart title
plt.title('What is the trend of the number of incidents reported in different areas of LA during the riots?', wrap=True)

# Set x-axis label
plt.xlabel('Date')

# Set y-axis label
plt.ylabel('Number of Incidents')

# Add legend
plt.legend(loc='upper left')

# Show plot
plt.show()
